description:
Anopheles stephensi is a species of mosquito that is a primary vector for the transmission of malaria in parts of the Indian subcontinent and the Middle East. It belongs to the Anopheles genus, which comprises a group of mosquitoes known to be the primary vectors for human malaria parasites.

Anopheles stephensi is a medium-sized mosquito with a distinctive pattern of pale and dark scales on its wings. It is an opportunistic feeder, feeding on both humans and animals, and is primarily active at night. The female mosquitoes require a blood meal to develop their eggs, and this is when they can transmit the Plasmodium parasites that cause malaria.

The breeding habitat of Anopheles stephensi includes a variety of man-made and natural water bodies, such as abandoned wells, overhead tanks, and rain-filled containers. This species has adapted well to urban environments and is considered a significant public health concern in many urban centers within its distribution range.

Efforts to control the spread of malaria often involve targeted interventions against Anopheles stephensi, such as the use of insecticide-treated bed nets, indoor residual spraying, and the elimination of breeding sites. Understanding the biology and ecology of this mosquito species is crucial for the development of effective control strategies and the reduction of malaria burden in affected regions.
